#Text=THE ARABIAN TUNNEL
#Text=That same evening , in 21 °30 ' N. lat . , the Nautilus floated on the surface of the sea , approaching the Arabian coast .
#Text=I saw Djeddah , the most important counting-house of Egypt , Syria , Turkey , and India .
#Text=I distinguished clearly enough its buildings , the vessels anchored at the quays , and those whose draught of water obliged them to anchor in the roads .
#Text=The sun , rather low on the horizon , struck full on the houses of the town , bringing out their whiteness .
#Text=Outside , some wooden cabins , and some made of reeds , showed the quarter inhabited by the Bedouins .
#Text=Soon Djeddah was shut out from view by the shadows of night , and the Nautilus found herself under water slightly phosphorescent .
#Text=The next day , the 10th of February , we sighted several ships running to windward .
#Text=The Nautilus returned to its submarine navigation ; but at noon , when her bearings were taken , the sea being deserted , she rose again to her waterline .
#Text=Accompanied by Ned and Conseil , I seated myself on the platform .
#Text=The coast on the eastern side looked like a mass faintly printed upon a damp fog .
#Text=We were leaning on the sides of the pinnace , talking of one thing and another , when Ned Land , stretching out his hand towards a spot on the sea , said :
#Text=" Do you see anything there , sir ? "
#Text=" No , Ned , " I replied ; " but I have not your eyes , you know . "
#Text=" Look well , " said Ned , " there , on the starboard beam , about the height of the lantern !

#Text=Do you not see a mass which seems to move ?

_	_	_	_

#Text= Certainly , " said I , after close attention ; " I see something like a long black body on the top of the water . "

column1: #Text=And certainly before long the black object was not more than a mile from us .
#Text=It looked like a great sandbank deposited in the open sea .
#Text=It was a gigantic dugong !
#Text=Ned Land looked eagerly .
#Text=His eyes shone with covetousness at the sight of the animal .
#Text=His hand seemed ready to harpoon it .
#Text=One would have thought he was awaiting the moment to throw himself into the sea and attack it in its element .
#Text=At this instant Captain Nemo appeared on the platform .
#Text=He saw the dugong , understood the Canadian 's attitude , and , addressing him , said :
#Text=" If you held a harpoon just now , Master Land , would it not burn your hand ? "
#Text=" Just so , sir . "
#Text=" And you would not be sorry to go back , for one day , to your trade of a fisherman and to add this cetacean to the list of those you have already killed ? "
#Text=" I should not , sir . "
#Text=" Well , you can try . "
#Text=" Thank you , sir , " said Ned Land , his eyes flaming .
#Text=" Only , " continued the Captain , " I advise you for your own sake not to miss the creature . "
#Text=" Is the dugong dangerous to attack ? " I asked , in spite of the Canadian 's shrug of the shoulders .
#Text=" Yes , " replied the Captain ; " sometimes the animal turns upon its assailants and overturns their boat .
#Text=" No , sir ; but I wish you good sport . "
#Text=The boat put off , and , lifted by the six rowers , drew rapidly towards the dugong , which floated about two miles from the Nautilus .
#Text=Arrived some cables-length from the cetacean , the speed slackened , and the oars dipped noiselessly into the quiet waters .
#Text=Ned Land , harpoon in hand , stood in the fore part of the boat .
#Text=The harpoon used for striking the whale is generally attached to a very long cord which runs out rapidly as the wounded creature draws it after him .
#Text=But here the cord was not more than ten fathoms long , and the extremity was attached to a small barrel which , by floating , was to show the course the dugong took under the water .
#Text=I stood and carefully watched the Canadian 's adversary .
#Text=This dugong , which also bears the name of the halicore , closely resembles the manatee ; its oblong body terminated in a lengthened tail , and its lateral fins in perfect fingers .
#Text=Its difference from the manatee consisted in its upper jaw , which was armed with two long and pointed teeth which formed on each side diverging tusks .
#Text=This dugong which Ned Land was preparing to attack was of colossal dimensions ; it was more than seven yards long .
#Text=It did not move , and seemed to be sleeping on the waves , which circumstance made it easier to capture .
#Text=The boat approached within six yards of the animal .
#Text=The oars rested on the rowlocks .
#Text=I half rose .
#Text=Ned Land , his body thrown a little back , brandished the harpoon in his experienced hand .
#Text=Suddenly a hissing noise was heard , and the dugong disappeared .
#Text=The harpoon , although thrown with great force ; had apparently only struck the water .
#Text=" Curse it ! " exclaimed the Canadian furiously ; " I have missed it ! "
#Text=" No , " said I ; " the creature is wounded -- look at the blood ; but your weapon has not stuck in his body . "
